abstract: From the beginning of the Civil War, American newspapers fought over what it would mean.
snippet: From the beginning of the Civil War, American newspapers fought over what it would mean.
lead_paragraph: One Saturday in late September 1861, Manhattan witnessed a scene that was becoming commonplace in countless New England towns and cities: well over 1,000 soldiers marched through the city, in the words of one observer, "Singing reverently and enthusiastically in praise of John Brown!" Abolitionism was hardly a universal idea, but the name on everyone's lips was that of its most fiery, violent advocate. "No military hero of the present war," the New York Independent noted, "has thus been honored."
